The Ramblings of Mister Nobody

April 28th, 2020: thoughts on webdev.

Thoughts on Web Dev

On the beginning of 2019 I started studying web development on my own. It's not easy at all if you work and do stuff to make a living. You're tired, you forget what you've studied yesterday and get frustrated.

As many do, I feel empathetic for people running over the same experience, and think my testimony may be useful for some of you.

First try

I've always believed this question was an easy one: do what you like.

It turns out to be rather difficult. I've Breath In and Breath Out deeply many times.

If it's the case that you like web development, and you build some spare hours out of nothing, then it's time to be efficient. I am not, but I try to be.

My take on this

What I did was probably a bit extreme, but I'll share it with you, just for the sake of having fun.

Some time ago I started travelling over the world with very little money. I was a chemist and thought it would be easy to find a job. Well it wasn't and I was not so sure to make it my job. Then I got into basic programming and web development.

I worked in coffee shops, waitering, and so on. Only to resign after 3 months or so to study for a while. And during this time, I did volunteerings, then the money lasted longer, and you always have spare hours to learn.

Sources of knowledge

On this days the hard task is not to get a book, or a document about a topic but to get the right one.

When I started studying it was because of Freecodecamp there were also group meetings on a library, and therein people helped newbies out a lot. Almost any online forum covers the same. There are also Youtube channels like Traversymedia, Kevin Powell, DevEd that help a lot if you are starting up from nothing.

freecodecamp does also have a forum where you can ask your questions. For more specific, general question there is stackoverflow and for sure there are IRC chat rooms or the new and super cool Matrix/Riot software to hangout with knowledgeable people and learn a lot from them.

What to learn?

I'd say learn HTML and CSS and start coding straight away. You can copy websites or learn simple stuff, code along with any Youtuber etc. I've always preferred to do all on my own. So I picked up a topic I was interested in and create a blog (after polishing my HTML, CSS/SASS skills to an intermediate level).

I believe the next thing to learn is mastering an editor. If you have a powerful computer go for vscode otherwise use vim. I use vim but it takes longer than any other editor to learn it and be productive with it.

I'd then, let's say on the 4th month, get into programming basics. Javascript and bash are absolutely useful. Knowing javascript you can go further to use gulp which is a workflow controller. It helps with repetitive tasks like compiling sass documents.

Looking for a Job

This is a tough part. I haven't find a job, not even as a freelancer. The reason being that many advanced coders are working both on industry and freelancing so it's not easy to find a job being a beginner.

That's why you should learn coding only if you like, because unless you can spend a lot of hours per day learning or learn things very fast, it will take long.
